block.p: Maker of Painkiller Is Urged By U.S. to Alter Marketing Federal officials have urged the maker of a widely abused narcotic painkiller to limit voluntarily how it distributes and markets the drug, which has played a role in more than 100 fatal overdoses in several states.
Federal officials have also been in talks about withdrawing or modifying a claim that the painkiller, OxyContin, made by Purdue Pharma, may be less prone to abuse than similar narcotics. [Page A16.]

Vodafone Seeks New Japan Stake The Vodafone Group of Britain is near a deal to acquire British Telecommunications' stake in Japan Telecom and its affiliate, J-Phone Communications, for about $4.3 billion, executives close to the discussions said. [C2.]

Vertex to Buy Aurora Biosciences Vertex Pharmaceuticals announced that it would acquire Aurora Biosciences for $592 million in stock, combining two biotechnology companies with expertise in different aspects of discovering drugs. The deal could presage further biotechnology mergers, analysts said, as stock prices have sunk and it has become nearly impossible for companies to raise money by selling shares to the public. [C4.]

Hollywood Reporter Editor Resigns Anita M. Busch, editor of The Hollywood Reporter and one of the top journalists covering the industry, resigned after a dispute over the publisher's initial refusal to print a story accusing the paper's gossip columnist of accepting favors from movie producers. [C3.]

Cheney Stresses Faith in Fossil Fuel Vice President Dick Cheney said oil, coal and natural gas would remain America's primary energy resources for ''years down the road'' and that the Bush administration's energy strategy would aim mainly to increase supply of fossil fuels, rather than limit demand. [A1.]

Halliburton to Acquire Magic Earth Halliburton, an oil services concern, agreed to buy Magic Earth, a company that specializes in the three-dimensional imaging of oil and gas deposits, for $100 million in stock. [C3.]

Technology Shares Edge Higher Technology stocks posted moderate gains as the Nasdaq composite index ended its best month on a percentage basis since June. The Nasdaq gained 40.56 points, or 2 percent, to 2,116.24. The Dow Jones industrial average fell 75.08 points, or 0.7 percent, to 10,734.97, and the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index fell 3.59 points, or 0.3 percent, to 1,249.46. [C8.]

Revival for 70's-Era TV Ads on Fox Fox turns back the clock for viewers with ''That 70's Show,'' a sitcom set during the decade of pet rocks and ''Saturday Night Fever'' and tonight, as a one-time stunt, the network will turn back the clock for Madison Avenue, too, running commercials from the 1970's during an episode of the show. Stuart Elliott: Advertising. [C6.]
Income and Spending Show Gains Personal incomes and spending rose in March, and manufacturing in the Midwest showed signs of emerging from a slump, government and private reports showed. [C3.]

McKesson Has Loss, but Shares Rise The drug wholesaler McKesson HBOC said it lost $175.5 million after charges in its fourth quarter, but the underlying results cheered investors and sent its stock soaring. [C13.]
Delta Pilots Continue to Weigh Offer The governing body of the pilots union at Delta Air Lines was still discussing whether to approve a tentative contract agreement. [C2.]
